characters.name: Judge Bao (Bao Zheng)
characters.story: Judge Bao Selling Rice in Chenzhou (Sept 17)
characters.scroll_quote: The law is not for the powerful alone; it is the scale by which Heaven weighs all under it.
characters.source: Judge Bao case stories; standard translation used in Judge Bao anthologies and course packet under, Judge Bao and the Rule of Law - Judge Bao Selling Rice in Chenzhou

interactions.greeting: You stand before the law. Speak carefully—truth echoes longer than words.
interactions.handoff: Take this decree. Justice must circulate like grain.
interactions.congratulation: You have acted without fear or favor. Heaven records this.
interactions.farewell: Go. Let fairness guide your steps.

characters.name: The Phantom Heroine
characters.story: The Phantom Heroine: Ghosts and Gender (Sept 29)
characters.scroll_quote: Though my bones lie cold, my grievance is not buried.
characters.source: Seventeenth-century chuanqi ghost stories discussed in The Phantom Heroine: Ghosts and Gender in Seventeenth-Century Chinese Literature

interactions.greeting: Do not fear me. Fear what was done while I still breathed.
interactions.handoff: Read this, and remember why I returned.
interactions.congratulation: You listened when others would not.
interactions.farewell: I remain until justice is done.

characters.name: The Corporeal Female Ghost
characters.scroll_quote: She ate with the living, spoke with the living, and yet no breath warmed her body.
characters.source: Discussed and quoted in “The Ghost’s Body,” commonly cited in analyses of embodied ghosts (translation varies slightly across scholarly editions)

interactions.greeting: You expected mist and shadow. Instead, you found flesh.
interactions.handoff: Take this proof that death does not erase presence.
interactions.farewell: Remember what a body can carry.

characters.name: Shen Xiu
characters.scroll_quote: The dead may not speak in court, but Heaven hears them all the same.
characters.source: Shen Xiu,” from Stories Old and New (Jingu qiguan), standard English translation

interactions.greeting: I have already died once. You need not bow.
interactions.handoff: This is what I returned to say.
interactions.congratulation: You have finished what I could not.

characters.name: The Wronged Ghost
characters.scroll_quote: When human judgment failed, the spirit came forth to accuse.
characters.source: Magistrate Teng,” Stories Old and New; narrative line used in standard translations

interactions.greeting: The living ignored me. You did not.
interactions.handoff: Carry my accusation where I cannot.
interactions.congratulation: Justice has weight, even beyond the grave.
interactions.farewell: I will trouble the courts no longer.

characters.name: Underworld Bureaucrat
characters.scroll_quote: In death, as in life, there are offices to pass and registers to be checked.
characters.source: The Chinese Deathscape,” introduction; discussion of afterlife bureaucracy

interactions.greeting: State your name. The dead queue as well.
interactions.handoff: Keep this record. Nothing escapes documentation.

characters.name: Hungry Ghost
characters.scroll_quote: With throats no wider than needles, they hunger without relief.
characters.source: Traditional hungry-ghost description cited in “The Chinese Deathscape”

interactions.handoff: This is all I was given.

characters.name: Qutu Zhongren
characters.story: Qutu Zhongren Cruelly Kills Other Creatures (Oct 22)
characters.scroll_quote: He took pleasure not in killing, but in cruelty itself.
characters.source: Slapping the Table in Amazement - Qutu Zhongren Cruelly Kills Other Creatures

interactions.greeting: Do you hear them? They never stop.
interactions.handoff: Take it. I don’t need reminders.
interactions.shun: You think this makes you better than me?

characters.name: Fox Spirit (Huli Jing)
characters.story: Alien Kind: Foxes and Late Imperial Chinese Narrative (Nov 3)
characters.scroll_quote: Do not ask whether I am human. Ask whether I am sincere.
characters.source: Late-imperial fox-spirit tales discussed in “Alien Kind: Foxes…”,Commonly cited fox-spirit sentiment across translations

interactions.greeting: Relax. If I meant to harm you, you’d never know.
interactions.farewell: We’ll meet again. Or we won’t.

characters.name: Ghost Witness
characters.story: Stories Old and New (general judicial ghost motif)
characters.scroll_quote: The ghost testified, and the case was finally resolved.
characters.source: Judicial ghost motif recurring in Stories Old and New (Jingu qiguan)
